newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - South Korean newspapers - May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Korean newspapers - May 23.

text.p: The following is a summary of major stories in leading South Korean newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy.
- Eight politicians on the Chung Tae-soo list indicted without physical detention.

- Inter-Korea Red Cross talks resume today in Beijing, 18 days after the first round of talks failed to produce the desired result of delivering food aid directly to the North by the South Korean National Red Cross (KNRC)
- A top Blue House official indicated on Thursday that President Kim Young-sam will not make an announcement about 1992 campaign funds.
- South Korean state prosecutors will indicate 15 governor of provincial administrations for accepting bribes and pre-campaigning.
- Kore's economy grew 5.4 percent in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) during the first three months of this year.

- Rumours that North Korea will invade the South between July and October this year, following de-facto leader Kim Jong-il's installation as the head of state in the North, are rampant among the communist state's population, according to recent defectors.
